Plugin.Details: Highlight part of the source code that should be analyze in a security audit.

Detector.Details: Detect the use of predictable Pseudo Random Generator (PRG).

BugPattern.Details:
The use of a predictable random value can lead to vulnerability if it is use for:

  • CSRF token
  • password reset token (sent by email)
  • or any other secret value

Detector.Details: Identify the unfilter value coming from ServletRequest and HttpServletRequest.

BugPattern.LongDescription: The method {3} return a String value that is control by the client.
BugPattern.Details:
The Servlet can read GET and POST parameters from various method. The value obtain should be consider unsafe. In may be needed to sanitize those values when calling sensitive api such as:

  • SQL query
  • File opening
  • Command execution
  • HTML construction
  • etc...

BugPattern.LongDescription: The HTTP header Content-Type can be control by the client.
BugPattern.Details: The HTTP header Content-Type can be control by the client.

BugPattern.LongDescription: The hostname received can often be control by the client.
BugPattern.Details:
The hostname can often be control by the client. Both ServletRequest.getServerName() and HttpServletRequest.getHeader("Host") have the same behavior which is to extract the "Host" header.

GET /test HTTP/1.1
Host: www.example.com
[...]

The web container serving your application may redirect request to your application by default. This would allow a malicious user to place any value. It is recommended to have no assumption on the value and therefor to proper escaping and validation if needed.

BugPattern.LongDescription: The query string can that any value.
BugPattern.Details:
The query string is the concatenation of the GET parameters and values. Parameter others that those intended can be passed.

For the url request /app/servlet.htm?a=1&b=2, the query string extract will be a=1&b=2

BugPattern.LongDescription: Request header can easily be alter by the client
BugPattern.Details: Request header can easily be alter by the client. No assumption should be make that the request come from a regular browser

BugPattern.LongDescription: The header "Referer" can be easily spoofed by the client.
BugPattern.Details:
Behavior:
  • Any value can be assigned to this header
  • The "Referer" will not be present if the request was initiated from another origin that is secure (https).

Recommendations:

  • No access control should be base on this header.
  • No CSRF protection should be based only on this value (Because it is optional).

BugPattern.LongDescription: The header "User-Agent" can be easily spoofed by the client.
BugPattern.Details: The header "User-Agent" can be easily spoofed by the client. Adopting different behavior base on the User-Agent (for crawler UA) is not recommended.

BugPattern.LongDescription: Request header can easily be alter by the client
BugPattern.Details: Request header can easily be alter by the client. No assumption should be make that the request come from a regular browser

BugPattern.LongDescription: Cookie value can be change by the client.
BugPattern.Details:
The information store in the cookie should not be sensitive or related to the session. In most case, session variables should be used. see HttpSession (HttpServletRequest.getSession())

Cookies can be use for information that need live longer than the session.

BugPattern.Details:
The class {3} is use to open a file handle using a dynamic parameter.

If unfiltered input is pass to this function, content from an arbitrary path could be read.

Detector.Details: Identify the usage of some FilenameUtils methods

BugPattern.Details:
FilenameUtils.{3} doesn't filter nullbyte.

The risk come from the removal of characters following the NULL byte. This removal can occurs with many system API (ie. usage of the File object).
